commands.name: Network Ping Sweep
commands.description: Discover live hosts on a network without port scanning

flag_explanations.-sn: Ping scan only - disables port scanning to quickly identify live hosts

success_indicators: Nmap done: X IP addresses (Y hosts up)
commands.notes: Use -sn for host discovery only, no port scan

methodology_guidance.after_success: Run full port scan on discovered hosts: nmap -p- <IP> Perform service enumeration: nmap -sV -sC <IP> Check for specific services (SMB, HTTP, SSH)

flag_explanations.-Pn: Skip host discovery - assume host is up (useful when ICMP blocked)
flag_explanations.-p-: Scan all ports (1-65535) instead of default 1000 common ports
flag_explanations.--min-rate: Minimum packet transmission rate per second for speed
flag_explanations.-oA: Output in all formats (normal, XML, grepable) for documentation

methodology_guidance.after_success: Service scan on open ports: nmap -sV -sC -p <PORTS> <TARGET> UDP scan if needed: nmap -sU --top-ports 20 <TARGET> Vulnerability scripts: nmap --script vuln -p <PORTS> <TARGET>

commands.name: Service Version Detection
commands.description: Detailed service enumeration with default scripts

flag_explanations.-sV: Service version detection - probe open ports to determine service/version
flag_explanations.-sC: Default NSE scripts - runs safe scripts for enumeration
flag_explanations.-p: Specify ports to scan (comma-separated or range)
flag_explanations.-oA: Output in all formats for documentation and analysis

commands.notes: Use after quick scan to investigate open ports

methodology_guidance.after_success: Research service versions for vulnerabilities: searchsploit <service> Web enumeration if HTTP found: gobuster dir -u http://<IP> SMB enumeration if 445 open: enum4linux -a <IP> SSH brute if 22 open: hydra -L users -P pass ssh://<IP>

commands.name: Vulnerability Scan

flag_explanations.--script: Run NSE scripts - 'vuln' category runs all vulnerability scripts
flag_explanations.-p: Target specific ports for vulnerability scanning

commands.notes: Can be slow, use specific scripts for better performance

methodology_guidance.after_success: Research found CVEs: searchsploit <CVE> Check Metasploit: msfconsole; search <vulnerability> Try specific vuln scripts: --script smb-vuln-ms17-010

commands.name: DNS Enumeration

flag_explanations.-t: Type of enumeration - 'std' performs standard record queries

commands.notes: Try zone transfer with -t axfr if allowed

methodology_guidance.after_success: Try zone transfer: dnsrecon -d <DOMAIN> -t axfr Subdomain brute: gobuster dns -d <DOMAIN> -w wordlist Check for virtual hosts on discovered IPs Reverse DNS on IP ranges: dnsrecon -r <RANGE>

commands.name: SMB Enumeration

flag_explanations.-a: All enumeration - combines -U -S -G -P -r -o -n -i (users, shares, groups, password policy, etc.)

commands.notes: Check for null sessions and guest access

methodology_guidance.after_success: Try null session: smbclient -L //<IP> -N Mount shares: mount -t cifs //<IP>/<share> /mnt Check write access: smbmap -H <IP> -u guest Brute force: hydra -L users -P pass smb://<IP>

commands.name: SNMP Enumeration

flag_explanations.-c: Community string for authentication (like a password)
flag_explanations.-v2c: SNMP version 2c - most common, supports bulk requests

commands.notes: Try 'public' and 'private' as default community strings

methodology_guidance.after_success: Extract user accounts: snmpwalk -c <SNMP_COMMUNITY> -v2c <IP> 1.3.6.1.4.1.77.1.2.25 Get running processes: snmpwalk -c <SNMP_COMMUNITY> -v2c <IP> 1.3.6.1.2.1.25.4.2.1.2 Try snmp-check for formatted output: snmp-check <IP> Brute community strings: onesixtyone -c wordlist <IP>

commands.name: SMB Null Session Share Enumeration
commands.description: Enumerate SMB shares using null session authentication (anonymous access without credentials)

flag_explanations.-N: No password - attempts null session authentication (anonymous login without credentials)
flag_explanations.-L: List available shares on the target server

troubleshooting.NT_STATUS_ACCESS_DENIED: Null sessions disabled on target. Try guest authentication: smbclient -U guest%guest -L //<TARGET>
troubleshooting.Connection refused: Port 445 filtered by firewall. Try legacy port 139: smbclient -p 139 -N -L //<TARGET>
troubleshooting.Protocol negotiation failed: SMBv1 disabled on target. Specify minimum protocol version: smbclient -N -L //<TARGET> --option='client min protocol=SMB2'
troubleshooting.No shares visible: Shares may be hidden from listing. Try connecting to common shares directly: C$, ADMIN$, IPC$, Users, Public

commands.notes:
Null sessions often allowed on older Windows (pre-2000) and misconfigured Samba servers.

This is the first step in SMB enumeration - always try before authenticated methods.

Document all discovered shares in enumeration.md.

Time estimate:
1-2 minutes.

OSCP tip:
If null session works, try accessing IPC$ for further enumeration with rpcclient.

commands.name: Comprehensive SMB Enumeration with enum4linux
commands.description: Comprehensive SMB/NetBIOS enumeration including users, shares, groups, password policy, OS info, and workgroup details

flag_explanations.-a: All simple enumeration - combines: -U (users), -S (shares), -G (groups), -P (password policy), -r (RID cycling), -o (OS info), -n (NetBIOS), -i (printer info). This is the most thorough single-command SMB enumeration.

failure_indicators: Server doesn't allow session using username

troubleshooting.Access denied but null session worked: Some info requires authentication. Get credentials and retry: enum4linux -u <USER> -p <PASS> -a <TARGET>
troubleshooting.RID cycling taking too long: Cancel and run faster targeted queries: enum4linux -U <TARGET> (users only), enum4linux -S <TARGET> (shares only)
troubleshooting.No domain/workgroup info: Target may be standalone. Focus on share and user enumeration instead of domain queries
troubleshooting.Connection timeout: Port 445/139 may be rate-limited. Reduce scan speed or wait before retrying

commands.notes:
enum4linux wraps multiple Samba tools (smbclient, rpcclient, net).

Best used after confirming SMB is accessible.

Time estimate:
3-5 minutes for full scan.

Can be noisy - IDS may detect.

Document findings in enumeration.md:
workgroup name, users, shares, password policy (useful for credential attacks).

OSCP tip:
Look for shares with READ/WRITE access, weak password policies (no complexity, no lockout), and user lists for credential spraying.

commands.name: CrackMapExec SMB Share Enumeration
commands.description: Enumerate SMB shares with authenticated access using CrackMapExec, showing detailed permission information

variables.name: <USERNAME>
variables.description: SMB username (or use '' for null session)

variables.name: <PASSWORD>
variables.description: SMB password (or use '' for null session)

flag_explanations.-u: Username for authentication (use '' or 'guest' for anonymous)
flag_explanations.-p: Password for authentication (use '' for empty password or null session)
flag_explanations.--shares: Enumerate all accessible shares and display READ/WRITE permissions

troubleshooting.STATUS_LOGON_FAILURE: Invalid credentials. Try null session: crackmapexec smb <TARGET> -u '' -p '' --shares
troubleshooting.No shares listed but command succeeds: User authenticated but has no share access. Try different user or check for hidden shares: C$, ADMIN$
troubleshooting.Connection timeout: Firewall blocking port 445. Try legacy port: crackmapexec smb <TARGET> -u <USER> -p <PASS> --shares --port 139
troubleshooting.Kerberos error: Domain authentication failed. Use local auth: crackmapexec smb <TARGET> -u <USER> -p <PASS> --shares --local-auth

commands.notes:
CrackMapExec is faster than enum4linux for share enumeration with known credentials.

Shows explicit READ/WRITE permissions which is critical for exploitation planning.

Time estimate:
30 seconds.

OSCP tip:
Look for non-standard shares (anything besides C$, ADMIN$, IPC$) and shares with WRITE access - potential for uploading payloads.

For null session:
crackmapexec smb <TARGET> -u '' -p '' --shares.

For multiple targets:
crackmapexec smb <SUBNET> -u <USER> -p <PASS> --shares

commands.name: Interactive SMB Client Connection
commands.description: Connect interactively to an SMB share for manual file browsing, downloading, and uploading

variables.name: <USERNAME>
variables.description: Username for authentication (use anonymous for null session)

flag_explanations.//: UNC path format for SMB shares: //<SERVER>/<SHARE>
flag_explanations.-U: Specify username for authentication (will prompt for password, or use %<PASS> inline for scripting)

success_indicators: Try "help" to get a list of possible commands

troubleshooting.NT_STATUS_ACCESS_DENIED: No access to this share. Try different shares from enumeration or use guest: -U guest%guest
troubleshooting.NT_STATUS_BAD_NETWORK_NAME: Share name incorrect. List shares first: smbclient -N -L //<TARGET>
troubleshooting.Cannot access subdirectories: Use 'cd <DIR>' to change directories. Use 'recurse ON' + 'prompt OFF' + 'mget *' for bulk download

commands.notes:
Interactive mode allows manual exploration which may reveal files missed by automated tools.

Common useful commands:
ls, cd, get, put, mget, mput, recurse, prompt.

Time estimate:
5-15 minutes for manual exploration.

OSCP tips:
(1) Check for readable files in Users directories - look for Desktop, Documents, Downloads.

(2) Check for writable directories - potential for malware upload.

(3) Look for configuration files, scripts, passwords in plaintext.

(4) For null session:
smbclient //<TARGET>/<SHARE> -N.

(5) For scripting:
smbclient //<TARGET>/<SHARE> -U <USER>%<PASS> -c 'ls;get file.txt'

methodology_guidance.after_success: Use 'ls' to list files Use 'get <FILE>' to download files Use 'put <FILE>' to upload files Search for sensitive files: passwords.txt, config files, SSH keys

commands.name: Recursive SMB Share Content Enumeration
commands.description: Recursively list all files and directories within an SMB share with detailed permissions

variables.name: <USERNAME>
variables.description: SMB username (or use 'anonymous' for null session)

variables.name: <PASSWORD>
variables.description: SMB password (or use empty string for null session)

variables.name: <SHARE>
variables.description: Share name to recursively enumerate (or omit -R flag to list all shares)

flag_explanations.-R: Recursively list files and directories within specified share (omit share name to recursively list ALL accessible shares)

troubleshooting.Access Denied: Credentials invalid or insufficient permissions. Verify with: smbmap -H <TARGET> -u <USER> -p <PASS> (no -R flag)
troubleshooting.Too much output: Pipe to file: smbmap ... > smbmap_output.txt, or target specific share: -R <SHARE>
troubleshooting.Slow enumeration: Large shares take time. Cancel and use specific share: -R <SHARE> instead of all shares

commands.notes:
smbmap shows file sizes and permissions which helps prioritize targets.

Use -A flag with patterns to search for specific file types.

Time estimate:
2-5 minutes depending on share size.

OSCP tips:
(1) Look for READ/WRITE directories - potential pivot points.

(2) Common sensitive files:
passwords.txt, users.txt, config.xml, web.config, *.ps1, *.kdbx (KeePass), id_rsa (SSH keys).

(3) Use download:
smbmap -H <TARGET> -u <USER> -p <PASS> --download '<SHARE>\full\path\file.txt'.

(4) For null session:
smbmap -H <TARGET> -u '' -p ''.

(5) Recursively list ALL shares:
smbmap -H <TARGET> -u <USER> -p <PASS> -R (no share specified)

methodology_guidance.after_success: Download interesting files: smbmap -H <TARGET> -u <USER> -p <PASS> --download '<SHARE>\path\file.txt' Search for specific files: smbmap -H <TARGET> -u <USER> -p <PASS> -r <SHARE> -A password Look for writable directories for potential payload upload

commands.name: Mount SMB Share Locally
commands.description: Mount an SMB share to local filesystem for direct file access and manipulation using standard Linux tools

variables.name: <USERNAME>
variables.description: SMB username (or use guest for guest access)

variables.name: <MOUNT_POINT>
variables.description: Local directory to mount share to (must exist)

flag_explanations.sudo: Required - mounting filesystems requires root privileges
flag_explanations.-t cifs: Filesystem type - CIFS (Common Internet File System, SMB protocol implementation)
flag_explanations.-o: Mount options - comma-separated: username, password, and other options
flag_explanations.password=: SMB authentication password (alternative: use file=<CREDFILE> for security)

failure_indicators: mount error(2): No such file or directory
mount error(6): No such device or address

troubleshooting.Permission denied: Invalid credentials or share not accessible. Verify access first: smbmap -H <TARGET> -u <USER> -p <PASS>
troubleshooting.No such file or directory (mount point): Create mount point first: sudo mkdir -p <MOUNT_POINT>
troubleshooting.No such file or directory (share): Share name incorrect. List shares: smbclient -L //<TARGET> -U <USER>
troubleshooting.Host is down: Port 445 blocked or host unreachable. Verify connectivity: sudo nmap -p 445 -Pn <TARGET>
troubleshooting.mount.cifs not found: Install cifs-utils: sudo apt install cifs-utils
troubleshooting.Password visible in mount output: Use credentials file: Create /tmp/smbcreds with 'username=<USER>\npassword=<PASS>', then mount -o credentials=/tmp/smbcreds

commands.notes:
Mounting allows using standard Linux tools (grep, find, cat, cp) instead of SMB-specific commands.

Much faster for bulk file operations.

Time estimate:
1 minute to mount.

OSCP tips:
(1) Always create mount point first:
sudo mkdir -p /mnt/smb.

(2) For null session:
username=guest,password='' or username='',password=''.

(3) For guest:
username=guest,password=guest.

(4) Unmount when done:
sudo umount <MOUNT_POINT>.

(5) Check what's mounted:
df -h | grep cifs.

(6) Force unmount if stuck:
sudo umount -f <MOUNT_POINT>.

(7) Use find for sensitive files:
find /mnt/smb -iname '*password*' -o -iname '*.config' -o -iname 'id_rsa'

methodology_guidance.after_success: Browse share: ls -la <MOUNT_POINT> Search for files: find <MOUNT_POINT> -type f -name '*password*' Copy files: cp <MOUNT_POINT>/path/file.txt ~/loot/ Unmount when done: sudo umount <MOUNT_POINT>

commands.name: HTTP Header Enumeration
commands.description: Enumerate HTTP response headers to identify server technology, versions, and potential security misconfigurations

flag_explanations.-I: Fetch headers only (HEAD request equivalent) - faster than full GET request
flag_explanations.-X: Specify HTTP method (GET, POST, OPTIONS, PUT, DELETE, TRACE) - useful for testing allowed methods

troubleshooting.Connection refused: Port incorrect or service down. Verify with: sudo nmap -p <PORT> -Pn <TARGET>
troubleshooting.No Server header: Header may be suppressed for security. Try: curl -I -X OPTIONS to see allowed methods
troubleshooting.403 Forbidden on /: Try different paths: /admin, /api, /login, or enumerate with gobuster
troubleshooting.SSL error for https: Self-signed cert. Use: curl -I -k https://<TARGET> (-k to ignore cert errors)

commands.notes:
Headers often reveal:
Server version (Apache/2.4.41), Backend technology (X-Powered-By:
PHP/7.4.3, ASP.NET), Framework (X-AspNet-Version), WAF presence (X-Sucuri-ID).

Time estimate:
10 seconds.

OSCP tips:
(1) Look for outdated versions - searchsploit material.

(2) X-Powered-By reveals backend language - useful for payload selection.

(3) Test OPTIONS method:
curl -I -X OPTIONS http://<TARGET> - may reveal PUT/DELETE allowed.

(4) Missing security headers = potential vulnerabilities:
X-Frame-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Content-Security-Policy.

(5) For HTTPS:
curl -I -k https://<TARGET> (bypass cert verification).

(6) Verbose for debugging:
curl -I -v http://<TARGET>

methodology_guidance.after_success: Research server version for vulnerabilities: searchsploit <SERVER_VERSION> Test for HTTP method vulnerabilities: curl -I -X OPTIONS http://<TARGET> Check for information disclosure in headers: X-Powered-By, Server

commands.name: Web Technology Fingerprinting
commands.description: Identify web technologies, CMS platforms, frameworks, JavaScript libraries, server info, and versions

flag_explanations.-v: Verbose mode - displays detailed information about detected technologies
flag_explanations.3: Aggression level 3 - good balance of thoroughness and stealth for OSCP labs

troubleshooting.Connection timeout: Increase timeout: whatweb -v -a 3 --wait 5 http://<TARGET> (5 second timeout)
troubleshooting.No technologies detected: Increase aggression: whatweb -v -a 4 http://<TARGET> or try --force-text for unusual responses
troubleshooting.SSL certificate error: Use -k flag: whatweb -v -a 3 https://<TARGET> (bypass cert verification)

commands.notes:
whatweb identifies:
CMS (WordPress, Joomla, Drupal), Web servers (Apache, nginx, IIS), Languages (PHP, ASP.NET, Python), Frameworks (Laravel, Django, Rails), JavaScript libraries (jQuery, Bootstrap), WAFs, Analytics.

Time estimate:
30-60 seconds.

OSCP tips:
(1) Prioritize CMS detection - WordPress/Joomla often have known vulns.

(2) Version numbers critical - check searchsploit immediately.

(3) For multiple URLs:
whatweb -i urls.txt.

(4) Check both HTTP and HTTPS:
whatweb http://<TARGET> https://<TARGET>.

(5) Look for development/staging indicators:
X-Debug, X-Error, verbose error messages.

(6) Admin panels:
/wp-admin (WordPress), /administrator (Joomla), /admin

methodology_guidance.after_success: If WordPress: wpscan --url http://<TARGET> --enumerate u,vp,tt If Joomla: joomscan -u http://<TARGET> If Drupal: droopescan scan drupal -u http://<TARGET> Research detected versions: searchsploit <CMS> <VERSION>

commands.name: Virtual Host Discovery with Gobuster
commands.description: Discover virtual hosts (subdomains) by fuzzing the Host header to find hidden web applications on the same IP

flag_explanations.vhost: Virtual host enumeration mode - fuzzes Host header instead of URL path
flag_explanations.-u: Target URL (must include http:// or https://)
flag_explanations.-t: Number of concurrent threads (default 10, increase for faster scanning)
flag_explanations.--append-domain: Append base domain to wordlist entries (e.g., 'dev' becomes 'dev.example.com')

failure_indicators: Error: the server returns a status code

troubleshooting.All entries return same size: Server returns same response for all hosts. Filter by size: --exclude-length <SIZE> or try different status codes
troubleshooting.No results found: Try common subdomains manually: dev, staging, test, admin, api, mobile, internal
troubleshooting.Connection errors: Target may have rate limiting. Reduce threads: -t 10 or add delay: --delay 100ms

commands.notes:
Virtual hosts allow multiple websites on one IP address by routing based on Host header.

Often reveals development/staging environments with weaker security.

Time estimate:
2-5 minutes depending on wordlist size.

OSCP tips:
(1) Always try vhost fuzzing on web servers - hidden apps common in CTFs.

(2) Use quality wordlists:
/usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/subdomains-top1million-20000.txt.

(3) After finding vhosts, add to /etc/hosts for browsing:
<IP> subdomain.domain.com.

(4) Common vhosts in OSCP:
dev, staging, admin, api, internal, vpn, mail, blog.

(5) Compare response sizes - identical sizes across all attempts = wildcard response (filter with --exclude-length).

(6) For IP-based scanning:
gobuster vhost -u http://<IP> -w <WORDLIST> --domain target.com --append-domain

methodology_guidance.oscp_tips: Add discovered vhosts to /etc/hosts: echo '<IP> vhost.example.com' | sudo tee -a /etc/hosts Browse discovered vhosts: http://vhost.example.com Directory enumeration on new vhosts: gobuster dir -u http://vhost.example.com -w <WORDLIST>

commands.name: DNS Zone Transfer Attempt
commands.description: Attempt DNS zone transfer (AXFR) to obtain complete DNS records including subdomains, IPs, and mail servers

flag_explanations.axfr: Zone transfer query type - requests complete copy of zone data (AXFR = Authoritative Transfer Full)
flag_explanations.@: Specifies which nameserver to query directly

troubleshooting.Transfer failed: Zone transfers disabled (proper security). Use subdomain enumeration instead: gobuster dns -d <DOMAIN> -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/subdomains-top1million-5000.txt
troubleshooting.Connection timeout: Firewall blocking port 53 or nameserver down. Verify: sudo nmap -p 53 -sU -Pn <NAMESERVER>
troubleshooting.REFUSED: Nameserver explicitly denies transfer. Try other discovered nameservers from: dig NS <DOMAIN>
troubleshooting.Don't know nameserver: Find nameservers first: dig NS <DOMAIN> or host -t ns <DOMAIN>

commands.notes:
Zone transfers should be restricted to authorized secondary nameservers only, but misconfigurations still exist.

Successful transfer provides complete DNS records - massive information disclosure.

Time estimate:
30 seconds.

OSCP tips:
(1) Always try zone transfer first - when it works, it's instant enumeration.

(2) Find nameservers:
dig NS <DOMAIN> then try AXFR on each.

(3) Parse output for subdomains:
dig axfr @<NS> <DOMAIN> | grep -E '^[a-zA-Z0-9]' | awk '{print $1}'.

(4) Look for:
internal hosts, dev/staging servers, admin interfaces, mail servers, database servers.

(5) If transfer fails (common), fallback to:
gobuster dns, dnsrecon -t brt, fierce --domain <DOMAIN>.

(6) UDP port 53 required - check firewall:
sudo nmap -p 53 -sU -Pn <NS>

methodology_guidance.after_success: If successful: Extract all subdomains and IPs from output Enumerate discovered hosts: sudo nmap -Pn -p- <DISCOVERED_IP> Add subdomains to /etc/hosts for further testing
methodology_guidance.on_failure: If failed: Try subdomain brute force: gobuster dns -d <DOMAIN> -w <WORDLIST>

commands.name: Two-Stage Nmap Chain
commands.command: TARGET=<TARGET> && mkdir -p nmap && PORTS=$(sudo nmap -p- -Pn --min-rate=1000 -T4 $TARGET -oG - | grep -oP '\d+/open' | cut -d/ -f1 | paste -sd,) && echo "[+] Discovered ports: $PORTS" && sudo nmap -sC -sV -Pn -p$PORTS $TARGET -oA nmap/targeted
commands.description: Two-stage scan: fast port discovery piped to targeted service enumeration

flag_explanations.-p-: Scan all 65535 ports - ensures no port is missed
flag_explanations.-Pn: Skip host discovery - assume host is up (useful when ICMP blocked)
flag_explanations.--min-rate=1000: Minimum 1000 packets/sec - speeds up discovery significantly
flag_explanations.-T4: Aggressive timing template - balances speed and reliability
flag_explanations.-oG -: Greppable output to stdout - enables piping to grep/awk for port extraction
flag_explanations.-sC: Default scripts - runs safe enumeration scripts on discovered services
flag_explanations.-sV: Service version detection - identifies service versions for exploit research
flag_explanations.-oA: Output all formats - saves .nmap, .xml, .gnmap for documentation

troubleshooting.No ports discovered: Host may be down or firewalled. Try: sudo nmap -Pn -sS -p 80,443,22,445 <TARGET>
troubleshooting.Scan too slow: Increase rate: --min-rate=5000 (may miss ports on unstable networks)
troubleshooting.PORTS variable empty: No open ports found. Check if target is reachable: ping <TARGET>
troubleshooting.Permission denied: Requires sudo for SYN scan. Run with sudo prefix.

commands.notes:
OSCP exam time-saver. Stage 1 (~3 min) uses fast SYN scan with greppable output to discover all open ports. Port numbers are extracted via grep/cut/paste and passed to Stage 2 for detailed service enumeration with version detection and default scripts.

Creates nmap/ directory with targeted.nmap, targeted.xml, targeted.gnmap output files.

Time estimate: 5-8 minutes total depending on target.

Manual alternative: Run nmap -p- first, note open ports, then run nmap -sV -sC on those ports.

Exam tip: Start this immediately when you get a new target IP - let it run while you read the machine description.

methodology_guidance.after_success: Review targeted.nmap for service versions. Search each version: searchsploit <service> <version>. Check for web services (80, 443, 8080) and enumerate with gobuster. Check for SMB (445) and enumerate with enum4linux.
methodology_guidance.on_failure: If no ports found, try UDP: sudo nmap -sU --top-ports 20 <TARGET>. Check if target is behind VPN or firewall.

commands.filled_example: TARGET=10.10.11.152 && mkdir -p nmap && PORTS=$(sudo nmap -p- -Pn --min-rate=1000 -T4 $TARGET -oG - | grep -oP '\d+/open' | cut -d/ -f1 | paste -sd,) && echo "[+] Discovered ports: $PORTS" && sudo nmap -sC -sV -Pn -p$PORTS $TARGET -oA nmap/targeted

commands.name: Two-Stage Nmap UDP Chain
commands.command: TARGET=<TARGET> && mkdir -p nmap && PORTS=$(sudo nmap -sU --top-ports 100 -Pn --min-rate=500 $TARGET -oG - | grep -oP '\d+/open' | cut -d/ -f1 | paste -sd,) && echo "[+] Discovered UDP ports: $PORTS" && [ -n "$PORTS" ] && sudo nmap -sU -sV -Pn -p$PORTS $TARGET -oA nmap/udp-targeted || echo "[-] No open UDP ports found"
commands.description: Two-stage UDP scan: fast top-100 port discovery piped to targeted service enumeration

flag_explanations.-sU: UDP scan - required for UDP port discovery (slower than TCP SYN)
flag_explanations.--top-ports 100: Scan top 100 most common UDP ports - balances coverage vs time
flag_explanations.-Pn: Skip host discovery - assume host is up
flag_explanations.--min-rate=500: Minimum 500 packets/sec - slower than TCP due to UDP characteristics
flag_explanations.-sV: Service version detection - identifies UDP services (DNS, SNMP, TFTP)
flag_explanations.-oG -: Greppable output to stdout - enables piping for port extraction

troubleshooting.Scan extremely slow: UDP is inherently slow. Reduce ports: --top-ports 20 for quick check
troubleshooting.All ports open|filtered: Firewall not responding to UDP probes. Try specific ports: -p 53,161,500
troubleshooting.PORTS variable empty: No open UDP ports or all filtered. Common - many hosts block UDP
troubleshooting.Permission denied: UDP scan requires root. Run with sudo.

commands.notes:
UDP scanning is MUCH slower than TCP due to protocol characteristics (no handshake, rate limiting). Run this AFTER TCP scan completes.

Common valuable UDP ports:
- 53 (DNS) - zone transfer, enumeration
- 67/68 (DHCP) - rogue DHCP attacks
- 69 (TFTP) - unauthenticated file access
- 123 (NTP) - amplification, enumeration
- 161 (SNMP) - major info disclosure if community string known
- 500 (IKE/IPSec) - VPN enumeration
- 514 (Syslog) - log injection

Time estimate: 10-20 minutes for top 100 ports.

Exam tip: Start UDP scan in background terminal while doing TCP enumeration. SNMP (161) is often a quick win if 'public' community string works.

methodology_guidance.after_success: If SNMP (161) open: snmpwalk -c public -v2c <TARGET>. If DNS (53) open: dig axfr @<TARGET> <DOMAIN>. If TFTP (69) open: tftp <TARGET> and try 'get' on common files.
methodology_guidance.on_failure: UDP often filtered. Focus on TCP exploitation. Return to UDP only if stuck.

commands.filled_example: TARGET=10.10.11.152 && mkdir -p nmap && PORTS=$(sudo nmap -sU --top-ports 100 -Pn --min-rate=500 $TARGET -oG - | grep -oP '\d+/open' | cut -d/ -f1 | paste -sd,) && echo "[+] Discovered UDP ports: $PORTS" && [ -n "$PORTS" ] && sudo nmap -sU -sV -Pn -p$PORTS $TARGET -oA nmap/udp-targeted || echo "[-] No open UDP ports found"
